trustfund: TF029143-PHRD-POPULATION/FAMILY PLANNING,TF030571-IDA CONSULTANTS POOLED CTF - FY04

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that rapid
            increase in contraceptive prevalence is possible in rural
            Africa through Community Based distributors. The project
            proved the hypothesis by demonstrating dramatic increase in
            family planning uptake in rural Malawi through a district
            wide Community-based Distribution (CBD) program. The project
            was successful due to a balanced focus on both demand and
            supply issues. Demand was increased through a very effective
            multimedia Information, Education and Communication (IEC)
            campaign. Sustainability is an important concern CBD
            programs that requires special attention. Notwithstanding
            the fact that the cost per CYP in this project is much lower
            compared to Zimbabwe (less than US$ 10 vs US$ 17 per CYP in
            Zimbabwe) sustainability was seen as the biggest challenge
            by the Ministry of Health and Population (MOHP). Lessons
            from this project have already been assimilated by the MOHP
            and are leading to several policy changes. First, the
            ministry is putting greater emphasis on community level
            activities. Secondly, PAC services at the district hospital
            are being provided by Clinical officers and discussions are
            on going to decentralize the services further to the nurse
            or medical assistant at the health center. And finally, the
            MOHP has seen the benefits of working closely with MASAF III.
